text.p: The following are the main stories from Wednewsday morning's German newspapers:
FRANKFURTER ALLGEMEINE ZEITUNG
- Economic growth of 2.25 percent forecast. Unemployment stays high, economic institutes say. They predict good chances for the euro planned single European currency.

- German Finance Minister Theo Waigel says Germany will be competitive in terms of tax once government has pushed its sweeping tax reform plans through. Chancellor Helmut Kohl's cabinet approves 1999 tax bill.
- European Court of Justice rules that it is in violation of European law to limit compensation for sexual discrimination in job applications to three months wages as prescribed in German civil law
HANDELSBLATT
- The European monetary union (EMU) will start punctually according to Germany's six main economic institutes.
- Mannesmann wants to nearly double returns on assets in next five years
- Chancellor Helmut Kohl's cabinet approves tax reform. Leaders of ruling Bonn coalition meet opposition Social Democrats to work out compromise on bill on Wednesday
- Kohl's Christian Democrats divided over whether they should allow dual nationality
- Ford AG chairman William W. Boddie praises "exemplary" agreement between management and works council to secure German industrial location and jobs into next century
SUEDDEUTSCHE ZEITUNG

- Bonn should qualify for launch of euro, according to Germany's leading economic institutes. Chancellor Helmut Kohl and Finance Minister Theo Waigel says Germany should be able to keep to budget deficit as percentage of GDP of 3.o
- German government approves Waigel's tax concept
- Row within Kohl's Christian Democrats over allowing German citizens to have a second passport becomes more heated
- Leading German economic institutes demands swift implementation of planned tax reform. Institute experts say political parties agree this would revive investment
DIE WELT
- Tax reform meeting lookes threatened with failure. Opposition Social Democrats Oskar lafontaine rejects Kohl's terms. Chancellery Minister Friedrich Bohl says an agreement will be difficult.
- Chancellor Helmut Kohl says his assessment of Germany's economy is confirmed by Germany's six key economic institutes.
- There is still hope, but the chances of agreement over tax between Kohl's coalition and the opposition SPD seems slim
- European Court of Justice rules that it is in violation of European law to limit compensation for sexual discrimination in job applications to three months wages
- Lull in consumption holds up economic upturn, Germany's leading economic institutes say. The institutes see no recovery in jobs market.
- European transport ministers want to make Europe's streets safer. They declare war on crime against goods traffic.
- Ford AG pledges to maintain industrial location in Germany and keep jobs beyond the year 2000
